text.p: The following are the main stories from Tuesday morning's Albanian newspapers. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
- The way local elections were conducted showed the opposition remained unable to compete with the ruling party and that nothing could be gained by merely complaining, newspaper editorial says.
- October 20 local elections were a confirmation of the results of the May general election, President Sali Berisha said at a news conference the day after voting closed.
- The opposition says Sunday's poll was another example of voter manipulation, which it claims were a feature of May 26 general elections.
- Most Tirana university students did not vote on Sunday.
- The ethnic Greek Human Rights Party suffered heavy losses and did not match the results of local polls four years ago.
- Albania started a partial privatisation of the chromium industry. German firm Preussag, which won the tender, plans to invest 80 million marks.
- Police have arrested 21 people suspected of belonging to a guerrilla group, which they say has committed many crimes in the last four years.
- Ethnic Greek organisation Omonia attacked Greece for not giving Albanian immigrants a guarantee they could return if they voted in Albanian polls on Sunday.
- Astrit Hafizi was elected coach of the Albanian national soccer team to replace Neptun Bajko, who resigned after a poor result against Portugal in a World Cup group nine qualifier.
- Ruling Democratic Party candidate for the post of Tirana mayor Albert Brojka won 54 percent of the votes and his opposition Socialist rival 38.4 percent.
- European observers said Sunday's local polls were free and fair.
- Three bombs exploded in three towns at the weekend, causing panic but no one was hurt.
- Lawyers of Klement Kolaneci, son-in-law of the late communist dictator Enver Hoxha, who was arrested last week on suspicion of having guerrilla links, say they are not allowed to meet him.
